Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column4: 2025|3370673|Executives|Martina Cheung|429194|640442511.0|2|Presenter Speech|118252367|2|0|"Thank you
column5: Mark. By any measure
column6: 2024 was an incredible year for S&P Global. Excluding Engineering Solutions
column7: which was divested in 2023
column9: and revenue from our subscription products increased 7%. We benefited from strong market trends
column10: including record debt issuance for our Ratings business and strong equity valuations for our index business.

column1: However
column2: we also continue to demonstrate the discipline and operational excellence our shareholders have come to expect from us
column3: delivering accelerated revenue growth in Commodity Insights and strong steady growth in both Market Intelligence and Mobility
column4: despite some market headwinds on those 2 businesses.

column1: We continue to take a balanced approach to profitability and investment
column2: which allowed us to make important investments in technology
column3: AI and products while still expanding margins more than 300 basis points. We delivered 25% growth in adjusted EPS in 2024. This exceeded the midpoint of our initial guidance range by more than 13%.

column1: Our disciplined approach to capital allocation allowed us to return $4.4 billion to shareholders over the course of 2024 through our cash dividend and the repurchase of 6.7 million shares. We expect to continue strong capital returns in 2025
column2: as we recently announced the 52nd consecutive increase to our cash dividend and a newly approved share repurchase authorization up to $4.3 billion. In total
column3: you'll see this would allow us to maintain our target of returning 85% or more of the $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow we are expecting in 2025.

column1: I've been very impressed with our people's ability to execute and deliver such strong results
column2: embracing the leadership transition and the increased focus on our customers and our enterprise advantages.

column1: With that increased focus on serving our clients at the enterprise level
column2: we announced the establishment of the Chief Client Office and the Enterprise Data Office. We're excited to share the successes from these initiatives with you as we progress through the year.

column1: We're also pleased to share that our new Chief Financial Officer
column2: Eric Aboaf
column3: will be joining us officially on February 19.

column1: We are gaining momentum in our product innovation and AI initiatives across the organization as well
column2: as I'll share with you in a moment.

column1: Lastly
column2: we continue the cycle of optimizing our portfolio of businesses
column3: so that we are best positioned for long-term profitable growth. In 2024
column4: we acquired best-in-class solutions to support strategic growth through Visible Alpha
column5: ProntoNLP and World Hydrogen Leaders. We also divested noncore businesses
column6: Fincentric and PrimeOne.

column1: One of my first priorities as CEO was to strengthen and deepen our relationship with key strategic customers at the highest levels of leadership. I had more than 100 meetings with some of our most important stakeholders to ensure a smooth transition of these key relationships.
These important discussions include not just our customers
column2: but also strategic
column3: commercial and technology partners. Together with our new Chief Client Officer
column4: I met 85% of our largest strategic customers just in the last 100 days.

column1: We are instilling in our executive leadership team
column2: a clear need to be where our customers are. Our success depends on the value we create and deliver for our customers
column3: so I've asked our division leadership to make these relationships a personal priority for them as well.

column1: This emphasis on customer engagement is a natural evolution for S&P Global. We've always made customer value a focus. But by making customer engagement a higher priority at the executive level
column2: we are building stronger relationships
column3: so that we can accelerate our response to customers' challenges.

column1: This engagement can also serve as opportunities to partner or co-invest with our customers. One such example is the UBS Leveraged Loan Index partnership. Through these many meetings
column2: I'm picking up a consistent set of themes
column3: which align very well with our competitive advantages and reinvigorate our optimism and confidence in our ability to compete and win.

column1: While generative AI is not a new topic for our customers
column2: they're moving beyond just considering what this technology can do and focusing on use cases that can scale quickly and contribute to strong financial results. Customers increasingly turn to us to benefit from our years of experience scaling AI technology from Kensho.

column1: We continue to see impactful headlines and market news on a near daily basis. Customers are deeply engaged to determine the potential impact to their business from tariffs
column2: regional competitiveness and other aspects of global trade.

column1: S&P Global is a world-class provider of data insights and thought leadership in these vital areas
column2: and our customers are turning to us for that expertise.

column1: Customers continue to feel the impact of the innovation taking place in financial markets with the flow of capital to passive funds
column2: but also increasingly to private markets and digital assets. Through our leadership in benchmarks
column3: private credit
column4: private equity workflow tools and innovation like our Stablecoin Assessments
column5: our customers see us as a critical partner in navigating this sea change over the coming years.

column1: Additionally
column2: customers recognize our leadership and seek our insights in energy transition. Energy transition is a complex issue encompassing energy security
column3: technology innovation and the financing of the various investments needed over the coming decades.

column1: For example
column2: in utilities
column3: the depth and breadth of our expertise and data sets across oil
column4: liquid natural gas
column5: carbon
column6: renewable energy
column7: electric utilities and reporting all helped drive the 23% growth in revenue from our energy transition and sustainability products in the fourth quarter.

column1: As we look to 2025
column2: we are hearing general expectations for some improvements in the macroeconomic environment. There is some variability by geographic region here
column3: with caution and uncertainty around Europe and Asia
column4: providing some ballast against the general optimism we're seeing in the U.S. markets.

column1: We are seeing strong demand for our products and some modest tailwinds from vendor consolidation. We continue to see the benefits from the breadth of our offerings
column2: as our enterprise approach allows us to meet more of our customers' needs in a more cost-effective way.

column1: As we've discussed for some time now
column2: we continue to see conditions in the financial services end market below what we would consider normal
column3: though we do expect a gradual improvement over the course of the year. We are also experiencing a highly competitive environment in financial services and somewhat elevated price sensitivity
column4: most notably impacting Market Intelligence.

column1: Now turning to the 2024 issuance environment. We saw nearly $4 trillion in billed issuance in 2024
column2: significantly outpacing our expectations
column3: with extremely favorable market conditions
column4: including tight credit spreads and lowering interest rates. We saw many issuers take advantage in 2024 to refinance debt and felt very strong activity in CLO volumes as well as repricing and amend and extend activity.

column1: While this does create a very difficult compare for 2025
column2: we believe the refinancing walls and a recovering M&A environment will contribute to modest growth in build issuance this year
column3: as we'll discuss in more detail in a moment.

column1: As we look next to the Vitality Index
column2: I'm encouraged that this index continues to accomplish its intended purpose. When we introduced this metric at our Investor Day in 2022
column3: we discussed the importance of making sure we were prioritizing new products that can contribute to our financial performance over time.

column1: We also noted that new products would remain in the Vitality Index for a finite time and would eventually mature out. The focus is to make sure that revenue from maturing products is replaced by new and enhanced products that can scale quickly. At the beginning of 2024
column2: we had a number of meaningful products mature out of the Vitality Index.

column1: Those products contributed a combined $330 million to the index in 2023
column2: nearly 25% of the total index. By continuing to innovate and invest in fast growing products
column3: we were able to more than replace that mature revenue and end the year with an index of $1.5 billion
column4: representing nearly 11% of total revenue.

column1: At the end of 2024
column2: we had another group of products mature out of the Vitality Index
column3: and we are confident that our focus on customer value and rapid innovation will once again enable us to deliver a Vitality Index at or above 10% this year.

column1: Turning to just a few examples of that innovation. As the world's leading provider of benchmarks
column2: we continue to invest and innovate to launch new benchmark products and make our existing benchmarks better. In 2024
column3: we expanded the collection of multi-asset class indices offered through S&P Dow Jones Indices
column4: and we launched the Leveraged Loan Indices in partnership with UBS.

column1: We continue to introduce new Platts price assessments every year
column2: and 2024 saw the launch of new assessments for various chemicals
column3: beef and poultry. We also introduced a first-of-its-kind product in the digital asset space to assess Stablecoins.

column1: We know that data and technology lay at the heart of almost everything we do
column2: so we continue to make meaningful investments in our internal technology and our technology products. We are finding new ways to leverage the remarkable data estate that we have
column3: and just one example of that
column4: in 2024 was the introduction of the market fixed income securities data in Capital IQ Pro.

column1: Part of our focus on technology must include a strategy to leverage the incredible technological advancement taking place in the world today
column2: such as generative AI. First
column3: beginning with our people. We are continuing to build a culture that embraces AI
column4: and we are empowering our people with the tools
column5: training and resources they need to thrive.

column2: we introduced our internally developed Copilot called S&P Spark Assist. Since introducing Spark Assist
column3: we have seen over 1
column4: 300 different use cases developed and shared internally across what we call our Spark Store.

column1: As we focus on developing AI skills across our entire workforce
column2: we are seeing our people truly embrace the use of these powerful tools to automate workflows
column3: more quickly ingest new information and more efficiently generate their own work products. We firmly believe that as we embrace the use of AI internally
column4: it will unlock significant potential for product innovation as well.

column1: Just as we learned with Kensho's incredible innovations over the years
column2: tools and resources that improve our productivity and efficiency will likely benefit our customers as well.

column1: Through ongoing customer meetings
column2: we hear
column3: again and again
column4: they want to be able to access and integrate S&P Global's data into their AI workloads. In order to expand and facilitate how and where customers can connect to our data
column5: we launched a new solution
column6: Kensho LLM-ready API that enables users to seamlessly integrate complex
column7: high-priority S&P Global data sets into generative AI models for their own internal use.

column1: It integrates with large language models like GPT
column2: Gemini or Claude
column3: allowing customers to use natural language to query our tabular datasets. This is all part of our ongoing effort to bring our data into this new era of GenAI and ensure that we are meeting customers where they are and where they are going in their AI journeys.

column1: We also embedded generative AI functionality in our major desktop applications
column2: including ChatAI for Platts Connect as well as ChatIQ and Document Intelligence for Capital IQ Pro
column3: all with the same vision of empowering our customers to more quickly and effectively gain insights from our data with AI.

column1: We also identified and acquired market-leading solutions that we believe strengthen our competitive position in multiple areas
column2: while contributing to the immediate financial results of the company. These include Visible Alpha and ProntoNLP in our Market Intelligence division and World Hydrogen Leaders in our Commodity Insights division.

column1: With the ultimate goal of driving profitable long-term revenue growth
column2: we will continue to lean into these kinds of innovation: development of tools for our own efficiency and productivity
column3: organic development of new products for our customers
column4: partnerships to develop new products and token acquisitions to accelerate the pace of scale and leadership.

column1: You'll notice that across these examples of innovation runs a common thread of generative AI. When we look at the potential for generative AI across the business over the next several years
column2: there are seemingly endless opportunities to innovate and add value for our customers. And with all this possibility
column3: we will ensure that S&P Global remains an indispensable partner to our customers as they adopt AI into more and more of their workloads.

column1: We're doing this in many ways
column2: including building sophisticated GenAI experiences
column3: laying the groundwork for agentive workflows and investing in foundational AI capabilities that help our customers more quickly and effectively gain insights from our data.

column1: In the coming quarters and years
column2: you'll see us lean more into practical applications that have the potential to move the needle on financial performance and enhance the value of our products. We will prioritize those use cases that improve our revenue growth potential
column3: improve our operational productivity and efficiency
column4: improve the capabilities and skills of our people and safeguard the security around our proprietary data and our systems.

column1: This will require us to say no to a lot of things
column2: but will allow us to effectively put investment dollars to work in ways that have the greatest potential to create real value. You've seen us do that in recent years with Spark Assist
column3: ChatIQ and many of the important innovations from our Kensho team
column4: and we will continue to highlight our progress in this important area going forward.

column1: Now turning to our financial results. Chris will walk through the fourth quarter results in more detail in a moment
column2: but we are pleased and encouraged by the results we delivered for our shareholders in 2024.

column1: We continue to see strong growth in our market-driven and our subscription businesses
column2: with total revenue increasing 14%
column3: or 15% excluding the impact of Engineering Solutions. We also delivered over 300 basis points of margin expansion in the year.

column1: As Chris will discuss in a moment
column2: we saw some elevated expenses in 2024 related to incentive compensation and commissions due to the very strong revenue beat this year. Were it not for that increase in compensation expense
column3: we would have had year-over-year margin expansion in every division.

column1: Now I'll turn to Chris to review the financial results."|Thank you
column2: Mark.

column1: Upstream Data & Insights revenue increased by 3%

column2: offsetting strong growth in our subscription-based offerings. The headwinds facing our Recall business began in early 2024

column1: Growth in financials and other accelerated to 18% as the business line benefited from strong underwriting volumes and market share growth. Adjusted expenses increased 7%. column2: primarily driven by growth in asset-linked fees

column1: Data & Custom Subscriptions increased 5% year-over-year as we continue to implement commercial initiatives across the various product offerings within the business line. However

column1: 2024 was a tremendous year
column2: and our financial results reflect that. As we look to 2025 and beyond

column2: primarily driven by growth in asset-linked fees

column1: Exchange traded derivatives revenue grew 4%

column1: Data & Custom Subscriptions increased 5% year-over-year as we continue to implement commercial initiatives across the various product offerings within the business line. However

column1: Adjusted expenses increased 15% year-over-year

column1: 2024 was a tremendous year

column1: Transaction revenue grew by 54% in the fourth quarter

column1: Advisory & Transactional Services revenue grew by 27%

column1: Upstream Data & Insights revenue increased by 3%

column1: Adjusted expenses increased 9%. Operating profit for Commodity Insights increased 11%

column1: And now turning to Mobility. Revenue increased 9% in the fourth quarter
column2: driven by demand for the CARFAX product suite and strong performance from our insurance-related products. Dealer revenue increased 10% year-over-year

column1: Manufacturing revenue increased 1% as the business line continued to see lower transaction revenue related to our Recall business
column2: offsetting strong growth in our subscription-based offerings. The headwinds facing our Recall business began in early 2024

column1: Growth in financials and other accelerated to 18% as the business line benefited from strong underwriting volumes and market share growth. Adjusted expenses increased 7%. Now turning to S&P Dow Jones Indices. Revenue increased 21%
column2: primarily driven by growth in asset-linked fees
column3: which benefited from higher AUM as well as growth in Data & Custom Subscriptions. Asset-linked fees were up 31%
column4: driven by market appreciation and inflows. In the fourth quarter
column5: we recorded net inflows of $486 billion

column7: along with market appreciation brought total ETF AUM to approximately $4.4 trillion.

column1: Exchange traded derivatives revenue grew 4%
column2: primarily driven by an increase in realized revenue per contract
column3: partially offset by slightly lower contract volumes.

column1: Data & Custom Subscriptions increased 5% year-over-year as we continue to implement commercial initiatives across the various product offerings within the business line. However

column3: Data & Custom Subscriptions would have grown by 10%.

column1: Adjusted expenses increased 15% year-over-year
column2: primarily due to increased incentive compensation
column3: combined with continued investment in our strategic growth initiatives. Indices operating profit increased 24%
column4: and operating margin expanded by 180 basis points to 67.9%. For the full year
column5: Indices operating margin expanded by 140 basis points to 70.3%.

column1: 2024 was a tremendous year
column2: and our financial results reflect that. As we look to 2025 and beyond
column3: the innovation and investment that we made in 2024 position us very well to continue delivering long-term profitable growth and create meaningful value for our shareholders.

column2: I'll hand it back to Martina to walk through the outlook and the guidance."|This resulted in operating profit increasing by 12% for the quarter and operating margin expanding by 100 basis points to 34.7%.

column1: Upstream Data & Insights revenue increased by 3%

column1: And now turning to Mobility. Revenue increased 9% in the fourth quarter

column1: Manufacturing revenue increased 1% as the business line continued to see lower transaction revenue related to our Recall business
column2: offsetting strong growth in our subscription-based offerings. The headwinds facing our Recall business began in early 2024

column1: Growth in financials and other accelerated to 18% as the business line benefited from strong underwriting volumes and market share growth. Adjusted expenses increased 7%. Now turning to S&P Dow Jones Indices. Revenue increased 21%
column2: primarily driven by growth in asset-linked fees
column3: which benefited from higher AUM as well as growth in Data & Custom Subscriptions. Asset-linked fees were up 31%

column6: which
column7: along with market appreciation brought total ETF AUM to approximately $4.4 trillion.

column1: Exchange traded derivatives revenue grew 4%

column3: partially offset by slightly lower contract volumes.

column1: Data & Custom Subscriptions increased 5% year-over-year as we continue to implement commercial initiatives across the various product offerings within the business line. However

column3: Data & Custom Subscriptions would have grown by 10%.

column1: Adjusted expenses increased 15% year-over-year
column2: primarily due to increased incentive compensation
column3: combined with continued investment in our strategic growth initiatives. Indices operating profit increased 24%
column4: and operating margin expanded by 180 basis points to 67.9%. For the full year
column5: Indices operating margin expanded by 140 basis points to 70.3%.

column1: 2024 was a tremendous year
column2: and our financial results reflect that. As we look to 2025 and beyond
column3: the innovation and investment that we made in 2024 position us very well to continue delivering long-term profitable growth and create meaningful value for our shareholders.

column5: Chris. Our financial guidance for 2025 assumes global GDP growth of 3%
column6: U.S. inflation of 2.3% and an average price for Brent crude of $72 per barrel. These all represent some degree of mean reversion from the figures we've seen over the last couple of years
column7: which we think should contribute to a stable issuance environment and a gradually improving backdrop for our financial services customers as we progress through 2025.

column1: We acknowledge
column2: however
column3: the degree of macro and geopolitical uncertainty that exists right now and that there is a range of potential outcomes beyond our base case assumptions. Our base case assumption is that we see at least one more rate cut this year in the U.S.

column1: We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. But as we've seen in recent years
column2: these rate movements are difficult to predict with a high degree of confidence. As such
column3: we are taking a prudent approach to our forecast for billed issuance. We expect low single-digit growth in billed issuance in 2025 from a record high base in 2024.

column1: Turning to our most recent refinancing study. When we compare these refinancing walls to last year's study
column2: we see that next 12-month maturities
column3: meaning 2025 maturities now compared to 2024 maturities measured at this time last year
column4: are approximately 4% higher than they were at this point last year.

column1: The maturities expected over the next 3 years
column2: however
column3: are approximately 1% lower than they were 12 months ago. Our billed issuance forecast takes both of these rates into account.

column1: The maturity walls make up just one of the factors we consider when providing an outlook on billed issuance. Given the record issuance here we've had and the deceleration we are expecting in 2025
column2: we wanted to provide some additional context around our outlook for low single-digit growth in billed issuance.

column1: Importantly
column2: we saw an acceleration in the pull forward of the 2025 maturity wall during the fourth quarter
column3: which impacts our outlook in 2 ways. First
column4: it drove stronger issuance than we expected during the fourth quarter of 2024. We saw that in our financial results
column5: and it creates a more difficult compare this year. Second
column6: it obviously decreases the amount of near-term maturities that are available to get refinanced in 2025.

column1: We continue to expect favorable market conditions around stable rates and credit spreads
column2: and we are encouraged by the robust maturity walls over the next few years
column3: all of which inspires confidence that issuance will see positive growth in 2025.

column1: Our outlook for the Ratings division assumes the refinancing of 2025 maturities and modest pull forward from the 2026 and later maturities. We also expect some improvement in the M&A environment relative to the last couple of years
column2: and there should be some tailwinds to issuance as a result.

column1: Lastly
column2: our expectation is that the mix of issuance is likely to shift slightly in favor of investment grade compared to what we saw in 2024.

column1: Against that backdrop
column2: we are introducing our financial guidance for 2025. This slide illustrates our guidance for GAAP results.

column1: Moving to our adjusted guidance. We expect revenue growth in the range of 5% to 7% in 2025. We expect adjusted operating margin in the range of 49% to 50%

column1: Through a combination of robust organic revenue growth

column1: Turning to our outlook by division. In Market Intelligence

column1: As a result

column5: Chris. Our financial guidance for 2025 assumes global GDP growth of 3%
column6: U.S. inflation of 2.3% and an average price for Brent crude of $72 per barrel. These all represent some degree of mean reversion from the figures we've seen over the last couple of years
column7: which we think should contribute to a stable issuance environment and a gradually improving backdrop for our financial services customers as we progress through 2025.

column1: We acknowledge
column2: however
column3: the degree of macro and geopolitical uncertainty that exists right now and that there is a range of potential outcomes beyond our base case assumptions. Our base case assumption is that we see at least one more rate cut this year in the U.S.

column1: We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. But as we've seen in recent years
column2: these rate movements are difficult to predict with a high degree of confidence. As such
column3: we are taking a prudent approach to our forecast for billed issuance. We expect low single-digit growth in billed issuance in 2025 from a record high base in 2024.

column1: Turning to our most recent refinancing study. When we compare these refinancing walls to last year's study
column2: we see that next 12-month maturities
column3: meaning 2025 maturities now compared to 2024 maturities measured at this time last year

column1: The maturities expected over the next 3 years
column2: however
column3: are approximately 1% lower than they were 12 months ago. Our billed issuance forecast takes both of these rates into account.

column1: The maturity walls make up just one of the factors we consider when providing an outlook on billed issuance. Given the record issuance here we've had and the deceleration we are expecting in 2025
column2: we wanted to provide some additional context around our outlook for low single-digit growth in billed issuance.

column1: Importantly
column2: we saw an acceleration in the pull forward of the 2025 maturity wall during the fourth quarter
column3: which impacts our outlook in 2 ways. First
column4: it drove stronger issuance than we expected during the fourth quarter of 2024. We saw that in our financial results
column5: and it creates a more difficult compare this year. Second
column6: it obviously decreases the amount of near-term maturities that are available to get refinanced in 2025.

column1: We continue to expect favorable market conditions around stable rates and credit spreads
column2: and we are encouraged by the robust maturity walls over the next few years
column3: all of which inspires confidence that issuance will see positive growth in 2025.

column1: Our outlook for the Ratings division assumes the refinancing of 2025 maturities and modest pull forward from the 2026 and later maturities. We also expect some improvement in the M&A environment relative to the last couple of years
column2: and there should be some tailwinds to issuance as a result.

column1: Lastly
column2: our expectation is that the mix of issuance is likely to shift slightly in favor of investment grade compared to what we saw in 2024.

column1: Against that backdrop
column2: we are introducing our financial guidance for 2025. This slide illustrates our guidance for GAAP results.

column1: Moving to our adjusted guidance. We expect revenue growth in the range of 5% to 7% in 2025. We expect adjusted operating margin in the range of 49% to 50%
column2: which represents up to 100 basis points of margin expansion beyond the high profitability level reported in 2024.

column1: Through a combination of robust organic revenue growth
column2: disciplined execution and strong capital returns
column3: we expect to generate adjusted diluted earnings per share in the range of $17 to $17.25

column3: with the highest retention rate we've seen in the last 6 quarters. That sets up the subscription business for improving growth
column4: but we would still be lapping the elevated cancellations from the prior quarters.

column1: As a result
column2: we expect the growth rate to be the lowest in the first quarter and improve as we progress through the year. Due to the timing of revenue recognition

column1: For Ratings

column5: Chris. Our financial guidance for 2025 assumes global GDP growth of 3%

column2: however

column1: We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. But as we've seen in recent years
column2: these rate movements are difficult to predict with a high degree of confidence. As such
column3: we are taking a prudent approach to our forecast for billed issuance. We expect low single-digit growth in billed issuance in 2025 from a record high base in 2024.

column6: U.S. inflation of 2.3% and an average price for Brent crude of $72 per barrel. These all represent some degree of mean reversion from the figures we've seen over the last couple of years
column7: which we think should contribute to a stable issuance environment and a gradually improving backdrop for our financial services customers as we progress through 2025.

column1: We acknowledge
column2: however
column3: the degree of macro and geopolitical uncertainty that exists right now and that there is a range of potential outcomes beyond our base case assumptions. Our base case assumption is that we see at least one more rate cut this year in the U.S.

column1: We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. But as we've seen in recent years
column2: these rate movements are difficult to predict with a high degree of confidence. As such
column3: we are taking a prudent approach to our forecast for billed issuance. We expect low single-digit growth in billed issuance in 2025 from a record high base in 2024.

column1: Turning to our most recent refinancing study. When we compare these refinancing walls to last year's study
column2: we see that next 12-month maturities
column3: meaning 2025 maturities now compared to 2024 maturities measured at this time last year
column4: are approximately 4% higher than they were at this point last year.

column1: The maturities expected over the next 3 years
column2: however
column3: are approximately 1% lower than they were 12 months ago. Our billed issuance forecast takes both of these rates into account.

column1: The maturity walls make up just one of the factors we consider when providing an outlook on billed issuance. Given the record issuance here we've had and the deceleration we are expecting in 2025
column2: we wanted to provide some additional context around our outlook for low single-digit growth in billed issuance.

column1: Importantly
column2: we saw an acceleration in the pull forward of the 2025 maturity wall during the fourth quarter
column3: which impacts our outlook in 2 ways. First
column4: it drove stronger issuance than we expected during the fourth quarter of 2024. We saw that in our financial results
column5: and it creates a more difficult compare this year. Second
column6: it obviously decreases the amount of near-term maturities that are available to get refinanced in 2025.

column1: We continue to expect favorable market conditions around stable rates and credit spreads
column2: and we are encouraged by the robust maturity walls over the next few years
column3: all of which inspires confidence that issuance will see positive growth in 2025.

column1: Our outlook for the Ratings division assumes the refinancing of 2025 maturities and modest pull forward from the 2026 and later maturities. We also expect some improvement in the M&A environment relative to the last couple of years
column2: and there should be some tailwinds to issuance as a result.

column1: Lastly
column2: our expectation is that the mix of issuance is likely to shift slightly in favor of investment grade compared to what we saw in 2024.

column1: Against that backdrop
column2: we are introducing our financial guidance for 2025. This slide illustrates our guidance for GAAP results.

column1: Moving to our adjusted guidance. We expect revenue growth in the range of 5% to 7% in 2025. We expect adjusted operating margin in the range of 49% to 50%
column2: which represents up to 100 basis points of margin expansion beyond the high profitability level reported in 2024.

column1: Through a combination of robust organic revenue growth
column2: disciplined execution and strong capital returns
column3: we expect to generate adjusted diluted earnings per share in the range of $17 to $17.25
column4: representing double-digit growth at the high end.

column1: Turning to our outlook by division. In Market Intelligence
column2: we expect revenue growth in the range of 5% to 6.5%. We exited 2024 with a very strong renewal quarter
column3: with the highest retention rate we've seen in the last 6 quarters. That sets up the subscription business for improving growth
column4: but we would still be lapping the elevated cancellations from the prior quarters.

column1: As a result
column2: we expect the growth rate to be the lowest in the first quarter and improve as we progress through the year. Due to the timing of revenue recognition
column3: the lapping of acquisitions and divestitures and the phasing of investments
column4: we also expect margins to be the lowest in the first quarter. However
column5: we expect to take a very disciplined approach to expense management in Market Intelligence this year and expect to deliver margins in the range of 33% to 34%
column6: representing 50 to 150 basis points of margin expansion year-over-year.

column1: For Ratings
column2: we expect revenue growth in the range of 3% to 5%
column3: as billed issuance growth and modest price increases are somewhat offset by expected unfavorable mix of billed issuance. We continue to take a balanced approach to investments and profitability in Ratings. And through continued expense discipline and improved efficiencies
column4: we expect to deliver margins in the range of 63% to 64%
column5: despite the slower expected growth in 2025.

column1: In Commodity Insights
column2: we expect revenue growth in the range of 7% to 8.5% and margins in the range of 47% to 48%. We expect continued robust demand for our energy transition products as well as our market-leading Platts price assessments.

column1: Given the long runway and secular tailwinds in this business
column2: we continue to invest to further distance ourselves from competitors in this space. Despite the ongoing investments
column3: we expect to deliver 20 to 120 basis points of margin expansion in CI with an expected margin range of 47% to 48% in 2025.

column1: In Mobility
column2: we expect continued strong growth in the range of 7% to 8.5%. We have reinvested revenue upside in the last couple of years
column3: which has tempered margin expansion
column4: but we expect the necessary pace of investment to slow somewhat in 2025. As such
column5: we are expecting margins in the range of 39% to 40%
column6: representing approximately 50 basis points of margin expansion at the midpoint.

column1: Lastly
column2: in Indices
column3: our guidance assumes relatively flat equity asset prices from the end of 2024
column4: given the very strong returns in the S&P 500 over the last 2 years. As such
column5: we expect revenue growth in the range of 8% to 10%.

column1: Given margins are already above our medium-term targets and given the attractive slate of investment opportunities in Indices
column2: we are making the decision to reinvest incremental profit for future growth in 2025. As a result
column3: we expect margins to remain relatively flat to 2024 levels and are guiding to a range of 69.5% to 70.5%.

column1: I refer you to our supplemental materials on our Investor Relations website for some additional details on our financial guidance
column2: but we are also expecting to deliver approximately $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow in 2020.

column1: Since the merger closed
column2: our free cash flow conversion rate
column3: or adjusted free cash flow as a percentage of adjusted net income
column4: has been at or above 100% every year and peaked in 2024 as we optimized our working capital and streamlined cash collections. This does create a difficult compare for working capital and free cash flow growth in 2025
column5: but we expect to maintain a free cash flow conversion rate at or above 100% in 2025 as well.

column1: In closing

column5: active to passive management and public and private market dynamics.

column1: We acknowledge
column2: however
column3: the degree of macro and geopolitical uncertainty that exists right now and that there is a range of potential outcomes beyond our base case assumptions. Our base case assumption is that we see at least one more rate cut this year in the U.S.

column1: We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. But as we've seen in recent years
column2: these rate movements are difficult to predict with a high degree of confidence. As such
column3: we are taking a prudent approach to our forecast for billed issuance. We expect low single-digit growth in billed issuance in 2025 from a record high base in 2024.

column1: Turning to our most recent refinancing study. When we compare these refinancing walls to last year's study
column2: we see that next 12-month maturities
column3: meaning 2025 maturities now compared to 2024 maturities measured at this time last year

column1: The maturities expected over the next 3 years

column1: The maturity walls make up just one of the factors we consider when providing an outlook on billed issuance. Given the record issuance here we've had and the deceleration we are expecting in 2025
column2: we wanted to provide some additional context around our outlook for low single-digit growth in billed issuance.

column1: Importantly
column2: we saw an acceleration in the pull forward of the 2025 maturity wall during the fourth quarter
column3: which impacts our outlook in 2 ways. First
column4: it drove stronger issuance than we expected during the fourth quarter of 2024. We saw that in our financial results
column5: and it creates a more difficult compare this year. Second
column6: it obviously decreases the amount of near-term maturities that are available to get refinanced in 2025.

column1: We continue to expect favorable market conditions around stable rates and credit spreads
column2: and we are encouraged by the robust maturity walls over the next few years
column3: all of which inspires confidence that issuance will see positive growth in 2025.

column1: Our outlook for the Ratings division assumes the refinancing of 2025 maturities and modest pull forward from the 2026 and later maturities. We also expect some improvement in the M&A environment relative to the last couple of years
column2: and there should be some tailwinds to issuance as a result.

column1: Lastly
column2: our expectation is that the mix of issuance is likely to shift slightly in favor of investment grade compared to what we saw in 2024.

column1: Moving to our adjusted guidance. We expect revenue growth in the range of 5% to 7% in 2025. We expect adjusted operating margin in the range of 49% to 50%

column1: Through a combination of robust organic revenue growth

column4: but we would still be lapping the elevated cancellations from the prior quarters.

column1: As a result
column2: we expect the growth rate to be the lowest in the first quarter and improve as we progress through the year. Due to the timing of revenue recognition
column3: the lapping of acquisitions and divestitures and the phasing of investments
column4: we also expect margins to be the lowest in the first quarter. However

column1: For Ratings

column4: 2025|3370673|Executives|Martina Cheung|429194|640442511.0|2|Presenter Speech|118252369|4|47|"Thank you
column5: Chris. Our financial guidance for 2025 assumes global GDP growth of 3%
column6: U.S. inflation of 2.3% and an average price for Brent crude of $72 per barrel. These all represent some degree of mean reversion from the figures we've seen over the last couple of years
column7: which we think should contribute to a stable issuance environment and a gradually improving backdrop for our financial services customers as we progress through 2025.

column1: We acknowledge
column2: however
column3: the degree of macro and geopolitical uncertainty that exists right now and that there is a range of potential outcomes beyond our base case assumptions. Our base case assumption is that we see at least one more rate cut this year in the U.S.

column1: We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. But as we've seen in recent years
column2: these rate movements are difficult to predict with a high degree of confidence. As such
column3: we are taking a prudent approach to our forecast for billed issuance. We expect low single-digit growth in billed issuance in 2025 from a record high base in 2024.

column1: Turning to our most recent refinancing study. When we compare these refinancing walls to last year's study
column2: we see that next 12-month maturities
column3: meaning 2025 maturities now compared to 2024 maturities measured at this time last year
column4: are approximately 4% higher than they were at this point last year.

column1: The maturities expected over the next 3 years
column2: however
column3: are approximately 1% lower than they were 12 months ago. Our billed issuance forecast takes both of these rates into account.

column1: The maturity walls make up just one of the factors we consider when providing an outlook on billed issuance. Given the record issuance here we've had and the deceleration we are expecting in 2025
column2: we wanted to provide some additional context around our outlook for low single-digit growth in billed issuance.

column1: Importantly
column2: we saw an acceleration in the pull forward of the 2025 maturity wall during the fourth quarter
column3: which impacts our outlook in 2 ways. First
column4: it drove stronger issuance than we expected during the fourth quarter of 2024. We saw that in our financial results
column5: and it creates a more difficult compare this year. Second
column6: it obviously decreases the amount of near-term maturities that are available to get refinanced in 2025.

column1: We continue to expect favorable market conditions around stable rates and credit spreads
column2: and we are encouraged by the robust maturity walls over the next few years
column3: all of which inspires confidence that issuance will see positive growth in 2025.

column1: Our outlook for the Ratings division assumes the refinancing of 2025 maturities and modest pull forward from the 2026 and later maturities. We also expect some improvement in the M&A environment relative to the last couple of years
column2: and there should be some tailwinds to issuance as a result.

column1: Lastly
column2: our expectation is that the mix of issuance is likely to shift slightly in favor of investment grade compared to what we saw in 2024.

column1: Against that backdrop
column2: we are introducing our financial guidance for 2025. This slide illustrates our guidance for GAAP results.

column1: Moving to our adjusted guidance. We expect revenue growth in the range of 5% to 7% in 2025. We expect adjusted operating margin in the range of 49% to 50%
column2: which represents up to 100 basis points of margin expansion beyond the high profitability level reported in 2024.

column1: Through a combination of robust organic revenue growth
column2: disciplined execution and strong capital returns
column3: we expect to generate adjusted diluted earnings per share in the range of $17 to $17.25
column4: representing double-digit growth at the high end.

column1: Turning to our outlook by division. In Market Intelligence
column2: we expect revenue growth in the range of 5% to 6.5%. We exited 2024 with a very strong renewal quarter
column3: with the highest retention rate we've seen in the last 6 quarters. That sets up the subscription business for improving growth
column4: but we would still be lapping the elevated cancellations from the prior quarters.

column1: As a result
column2: we expect the growth rate to be the lowest in the first quarter and improve as we progress through the year. Due to the timing of revenue recognition
column3: the lapping of acquisitions and divestitures and the phasing of investments
column4: we also expect margins to be the lowest in the first quarter. However
column5: we expect to take a very disciplined approach to expense management in Market Intelligence this year and expect to deliver margins in the range of 33% to 34%
column6: representing 50 to 150 basis points of margin expansion year-over-year.

column1: For Ratings
column2: we expect revenue growth in the range of 3% to 5%
column3: as billed issuance growth and modest price increases are somewhat offset by expected unfavorable mix of billed issuance. We continue to take a balanced approach to investments and profitability in Ratings. And through continued expense discipline and improved efficiencies
column4: we expect to deliver margins in the range of 63% to 64%
column5: despite the slower expected growth in 2025.

column1: In Commodity Insights
column2: we expect revenue growth in the range of 7% to 8.5% and margins in the range of 47% to 48%. We expect continued robust demand for our energy transition products as well as our market-leading Platts price assessments.

column1: Given the long runway and secular tailwinds in this business
column2: we continue to invest to further distance ourselves from competitors in this space. Despite the ongoing investments
column3: we expect to deliver 20 to 120 basis points of margin expansion in CI with an expected margin range of 47% to 48% in 2025.

column1: In Mobility
column2: we expect continued strong growth in the range of 7% to 8.5%. We have reinvested revenue upside in the last couple of years
column3: which has tempered margin expansion
column4: but we expect the necessary pace of investment to slow somewhat in 2025. As such
column5: we are expecting margins in the range of 39% to 40%
column6: representing approximately 50 basis points of margin expansion at the midpoint.

column1: Lastly
column2: in Indices
column3: our guidance assumes relatively flat equity asset prices from the end of 2024
column4: given the very strong returns in the S&P 500 over the last 2 years. As such
column5: we expect revenue growth in the range of 8% to 10%.

column1: Given margins are already above our medium-term targets and given the attractive slate of investment opportunities in Indices
column2: we are making the decision to reinvest incremental profit for future growth in 2025. As a result
column3: we expect margins to remain relatively flat to 2024 levels and are guiding to a range of 69.5% to 70.5%.

column1: I refer you to our supplemental materials on our Investor Relations website for some additional details on our financial guidance
column2: but we are also expecting to deliver approximately $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow in 2020.

column1: Since the merger closed
column2: our free cash flow conversion rate
column3: or adjusted free cash flow as a percentage of adjusted net income
column4: has been at or above 100% every year and peaked in 2024 as we optimized our working capital and streamlined cash collections. This does create a difficult compare for working capital and free cash flow growth in 2025
column5: but we expect to maintain a free cash flow conversion rate at or above 100% in 2025 as well.

column1: In closing
column2: through the various leadership roles I've held over the last 15 years within S&P Global
column3: I've seen the ins and outs of our businesses up close at every stage of the cycle. Our company sits at the crossroads with so many vitally important secular trends: data and artificial intelligence
column4: energy transition
column5: active to passive management and public and private market dynamics.

column1: We also sit at the nexus of all the major global markets: equity
column2: fixed income and commodities. We have the right people in place
column3: we are making the right investments
column4: and we are building the right strategy. It's an incredibly exciting time to be at S&P Global.

column1: With that
column2: we will turn the call back over to Mark for your questions."|Given margins are already above our medium-term targets and given the attractive slate of investment opportunities in Indices
column3: we are making the decision to reinvest incremental profit for future growth in 2025.

column1: We acknowledge
column2: however
column3: the degree of macro and geopolitical uncertainty that exists right now and that there is a range of potential outcomes beyond our base case assumptions. Our base case assumption is that we see at least one more rate cut this year in the U.S.

column1: We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. But as we've seen in recent years
column2: these rate movements are difficult to predict with a high degree of confidence. As such
column3: we are taking a prudent approach to our forecast for billed issuance. We expect low single-digit growth in billed issuance in 2025 from a record high base in 2024.

column1: Turning to our most recent refinancing study. When we compare these refinancing walls to last year's study
column2: we see that next 12-month maturities

column1: The maturities expected over the next 3 years

column1: The maturity walls make up just one of the factors we consider when providing an outlook on billed issuance. Given the record issuance here we've had and the deceleration we are expecting in 2025

column1: Importantly
column2: we saw an acceleration in the pull forward of the 2025 maturity wall during the fourth quarter
column3: which impacts our outlook in 2 ways. First
column4: it drove stronger issuance than we expected during the fourth quarter of 2024. We saw that in our financial results
column5: and it creates a more difficult compare this year. Second

column1: We continue to expect favorable market conditions around stable rates and credit spreads
column2: and we are encouraged by the robust maturity walls over the next few years
column3: all of which inspires confidence that issuance will see positive growth in 2025.

column1: Our outlook for the Ratings division assumes the refinancing of 2025 maturities and modest pull forward from the 2026 and later maturities. We also expect some improvement in the M&A environment relative to the last couple of years

column1: Lastly

column4: but we would still be lapping the elevated cancellations from the prior quarters.

column1: As a result
column2: we expect the growth rate to be the lowest in the first quarter and improve as we progress through the year. Due to the timing of revenue recognition

column1: We acknowledge
column2: however
column3: the degree of macro and geopolitical uncertainty that exists right now and that there is a range of potential outcomes beyond our base case assumptions. Our base case assumption is that we see at least one more rate cut this year in the U.S.

column1: We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. But as we've seen in recent years
column2: these rate movements are difficult to predict with a high degree of confidence. As such
column3: we are taking a prudent approach to our forecast for billed issuance. We expect low single-digit growth in billed issuance in 2025 from a record high base in 2024.

column1: Importantly

column3: which impacts our outlook in 2 ways. First

column6: it obviously decreases the amount of near-term maturities that are available to get refinanced in 2025.

column1: We continue to expect favorable market conditions around stable rates and credit spreads

column3: all of which inspires confidence that issuance will see positive growth in 2025.

column5: thanks so much for your question. I would say as a matter of course and for a complete management team
column6: we're always looking at optimizing across our overall portfolio to make sure we're the right owners of any particular products.

column4: of course

column3: in Q4
column4: as we mentioned
column5: we had very strong performance on retention. We had the lowest the level of cancels that we had in well over a year
column6: and we were able to do that through strong customer engagement and really strong differentiation in the products that we have.

column1: Importantly
column2: we saw good competitive wins and no competitive losses in that quarter. And we did that without needing to pull forward any of the pipeline from Q1
column3: for example.

column1: So we do feel that we are starting off with the new leadership team in a good position. column2: that was a comment overall for Market Intelligence. And specifically
column3: just calling back to the earlier quarters last year where we did see elevated cancellations and we did see some softness that we were calling out in the financial's end market
column4: in Q4
column5: we had that very strong retention rate with lower cancellations.

column1: So on the one hand
column2: we would expect to continue to experience and lap the cancellations from earlier in the year. column5: thanks so much for your question. I would say as a matter of course and for a complete management team
column6: we're always looking at optimizing across our overall portfolio to make sure we're the right owners of any particular products.

column1: And we want to make sure
column2: of course
column3: that the collection of products that we have is doing the best possible to create value for our clients and also
column4: of course
column5: for our shareholders. So that's something that we'll continue to do across the enterprise.

column1: In terms of the Market Intelligence performance going into 2025
column2: maybe I'll go back to a little bit of some of the remarks and add some additional context. So for example
column3: in Q4
column4: as we mentioned
column5: we had very strong performance on retention. We had the lowest the level of cancels that we had in well over a year
column6: and we were able to do that through strong customer engagement and really strong differentiation in the products that we have.

column1: Importantly
column2: we saw good competitive wins and no competitive losses in that quarter. And we did that without needing to pull forward any of the pipeline from Q1
column3: for example.

column1: So we do feel that we are starting off with the new leadership team in a good position. The new leadership team has been incredibly focused on making sure that we're aligning our go-to-market efforts to best meet our customers' needs and also focus on simplifying and making sure that we are completely overall focused on growth in the business.
To your question on the ACV and the specific pressure
column2: that was a comment overall for Market Intelligence. And specifically
column3: just calling back to the earlier quarters last year where we did see elevated cancellations and we did see some softness that we were calling out in the financial's end market
column4: in Q4
column5: we had that very strong retention rate with lower cancellations.

column1: So on the one hand
column2: we would expect to continue to experience and lap the cancellations from earlier in the year. That informs our view on maybe a softer start to the year and gradual improvement throughout the course of the year as we lap those cancellations. But also we saw what we think is the beginnings of a recovery in the financial end markets
column3: and we'd expect that to gradually improve throughout the course of the year as well. Thanks for the question."|That informs our view on maybe a softer start to the year and gradual improvement throughout the course of the year as we lap those cancellations.

Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column4: 2025|3370673|Executives|Martina Cheung|429194|640442511.0|4|Answer|118252376|11|0|"Great. Alex
column5: thanks so much for the question. What I would say is on the ACV growth
column6: that was contributed to a point or 2 of additional revenue growth for us -- faster revenue growth for us.

column1: But maybe just to take a step back on what happened in Q4. Q4 is actually our largest renewal quarter
column2: and that's one of the reasons why we're very
column3: very pleased with the results that we saw there and the positioning for us going into 2025.

column1: And then to the management changes
column2: I would say it's a new leadership team. We are very focused on simplification
column3: eliminating silos in the business
column4: making sure that the business lines are communicating and working very well together to ensure that we're bringing the greatest value to our customers.

column1: We're also incredibly focused on making sure that we can accelerate where possible the go-to-market strategy around new products
column2: and some of those that are very interesting and give us a great step in the door with our clients would be some of the new additions to our Desktop
column3: for example
column4: Document Intelligence and ChatIQ
column5: but also things like getting our market fixed income data out onto our Desktop product as well as our Kensho LLM-ready APIs.

column1: So a lot of innovation focused on execution
column2: focused on making sure that the team is operating in the highest level of efficiency and integrating GenAI where possible."|Great.

column4: 2025|3370673|Analysts|Faiza Alwy|184090|54721260.0|3|Question|118252380|15|0|"So I wanted to ask about Ratings outlook. I think
column5: Martina
column6: you mentioned that you're being prudent. So curious around how much visibility do you have at this point.

column1: What are you expecting in terms of an M&A contribution? And maybe the best way to answer this is if you could give us any color with respect to quarterly cadence around revenue growth within the Ratings segment?"|"So I wanted to ask about Ratings outlook. I think
column2: Martina
column3: you mentioned that you're being prudent. So curious around how much visibility do you have at this point.

column1: What are you expecting in terms of an M&A contribution? And maybe the best way to answer this is if you could give us any color with respect to quarterly cadence around revenue growth within the Ratings segment?"

column2: Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column5: thanks so much for the question. Maybe just to answer the last question there
column6: the last part of that
column7: we don't guide on a quarterly basis
column8: but let me take a step back and give you a little bit of context for how we're thinking about the Ratings outlook.

column1: Our base case as we outlined includes
column2: we would say
column3: kind of modest expectations on the rate cut front
column4: just one more cut to about 4.1%
column5: for example
column6: in the U.S. in 2025. I think
column7: importantly
column8: we don't assume a protracted trade war. We do not assume massive changes around economic growth
column9: both in the U.S. and as well as across our existing assumptions for -- and forecast for economic growth in other regions. And I think it's important to note that we would assume we continue to see favorable conditions with tight spreads as we go throughout the year for 2025.

column1: Then more specifically
column2: we had in Q4 an interesting quarter. We had been signaling throughout the course of last year that we did expect the back half of the year to be slower. And then
column3: obviously
column4: as we went through into Q3
column5: we were still signaling that we thought Q4 was going to be a bit softer. And then Q4 outperformed
column6: as you saw in our financial results. The result there
column7: of course
column8: is that it has reduced the level of maturities that we were anticipating to come to market in 2025.

column1: Now that being said
column2: as I said in the prepared remarks
column3: we're still about 4% higher relative to this time last year in terms of in-year maturities. So the low single-digit guide on the billed issuance point is a combination of full maturity drawdown for '25
column4: some very modest pull forward from '26 and out years.

column1: And then we have modeled in what I would characterize as modest expectations for recovery in M&A. We're not overly optimistic on that. We're still keeping a very balanced view on what we would expect from an opportunistic issuance standpoint.
I guess
column2: the only other point I would make just on the issuance point is just calling your attention to the fact that we expect a slight skew towards investment grade. And of course

column1: Then more specifically

column3: Feb 11
column4: 2025|3370673|Executives|Martina Cheung|429194|640442511.0|4|Answer|118252384|19|0|"Yes. Ashish
column5: thanks so much for your question. And maybe just to take a step back
column6: we were obviously very pleased with the 2024 full year results on margins and achieving our IR Day margin range. We -- as you see from our guidance in 2025
column7: we're at the high end of the guidance range from IR Day

column1: First
column2: we are extremely disciplined around expense management. One of the core operating motions for this leadership team is making sure that we are putting every next dollar to work in the place where we can see the greatest return for value creation for our customers
column3: but also long-term shareholder value
column4: and that is giving us some ideas around how we can actually be more efficient.

column1: We're looking at location strategy. We're looking at efficiency throughout our infrastructure
column2: our cloud spend
column3: et cetera. And then
column4: very importantly
column5: we're integrating AI across the organization. You heard us talk about Spark Assist. We have almost 30
column6: 000 users on Spark Assist.

column1: Every one of those users is finding ways to spend less time doing some of the more mundane tasks and more time on the value-added tasks. So that's an area of great excitement for us. And some of that productivity gain is reflected in the margin guidance that we provided today."|Yes.

column3: you said in the prepared remarks

Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column5: thanks so much for your question. I would say that the comment in the prepared remarks is largely a reflection on what we were seeing in the financial end markets. We commented throughout the course of last year that in addition to the softness -- somewhat softness in the markets that we did see increased competition and price sensitivity.

column1: Now all that being said
column2: in Q4
column3: we saw a couple of trends
column4: which are important for us and things that we want to continue to focus on. The first is our competitive breadth in terms of all of the products that we can bring
column5: not just within Market Intelligence
column6: but we're also seeing opportunities to connect in other products
column7: for example

column1: That breadth allows us to position ourselves for opportunities where we can benefit from vendor consolidation activity with our clients. We want to make sure we're very focused on that going forward.
Another thing I would say is that we have an opportunity here
column2: and we're seeing it already in the conversations that have taken place through the Chief Client Office
column3: but we think that there could be some good opportunities here just to make sure that we're bringing everything that we can to our clients.

column1: In some cases
column2: our clients may not even know the full picture of how they can benefit from the products and services that they're purchasing from us. And so the strengthened -- strengthening the relationships is a way for us to make sure they're getting the most value and that we're getting opportunities to demonstrate more ways to create value for them. So that's on the competitive environment
column3: but also how we differentiate ourselves.

column1: I think on price
column2: we believe we have a very differentiated set of capabilities
column3: and we will always try to align the price with the value that we create for the -- for our clients. Obviously
column4: we don't sort of guide forward on that. But that's really a -- at the intersection of the value we create for our clients and the economics that we have with them. Thanks for the question."|Toni
column5: thanks so much for your question.

column2: Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column4: 2025|3370673|Executives|Christopher Craig|616529|580018838.0|4|Answer|118252391|26|0|Jeff
column5: thanks for your question. First
column6: our exposure -- to your first question
column7: our exposure to the U.S. government contracts is less than 1% of our consolidated revenue. And then just really looking at exchange rates
column9: we do expect variability in exchange rates that could impact revenue. But we do have natural hedges in place from the geographic distribution of our people as well as an active hedging program to mitigate any EPS risk from foreign exchange rates. And just for modeling purposes
column10: our guidance assumes that foreign exchange rates as of mid-January.|Jeff
column11: thanks for your question.

column2: Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column5: it's Martina. Thanks so much for the question. Well
column6: we will be
column7: as I've commented
column8: lapping higher cancellations from 2024 in the first part of the year. So as you think about the course of the year
column9: as I said
column10: we would be expecting a softer first half compared to second half
column11: with gradual improvement in both the book of business from an ACV standpoint as we lap those cancellations
column12: but also the external environment for financial services where we had been highlighting that softness throughout the course of last year.

column1: The
column2: I would say
column3: competitive differentiation that we have has contributed to some strong competitive wins. We're excited about that. Of course
column4: our goal is to continue that. But importantly
column5: I think we saw no competitive losses in Q4
column6: which was
column7: I think
column8: a really good sign for the stepped-up initiatives around go-to-market with the Market Intelligence commercial team.

column1: And overall
column2: we continue to work across the organization
column3: partnering closely with the Chief Client Office as well. So thanks so much for that question
column4: George."|George

column2: Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column5: thanks for the question. I would say
column6: look
column7: we definitely have hit back to -- in fact
column9: which is the last high watermark and certainly higher than prepandemic levels with the 2024.

column1: So to some extent
column2: I think '25 is difficult because you have that very challenging comparable. But the market volumes generally we see as being back to the levels that we would have expected. And that
column3: as you know
column4: has informed our views on our billed issuance guidance as well as our overall guidance for 2025.

column1: On M&A
column2: we are always balanced. We know that there's a very healthy optimism in the market around M&A. We've been
column3: I would say
column4: prudent
column5: and we have modest expectations from M&A volumes and opportunistic issuance this year.

column1: We always look at this
column2: as you know
column3: with the facts and the information that we have at a given point in time. And this is -- issuance
column4: in particular
column5: is inherently challenging to predict
column6: but this is how we see it today. And of course
column7: to the extent that we see things that could change our guidance range
column8: we would certainly come back to you on that."|Andrew

column4: 2025|3370673|Analysts|Andrew Nicholas|342145|537531046.0|3|Question|118252400|35|0|"Martina
column5: in your prepared remarks
column6: I think I caught you saying that you'd lean more into practical AI applications in the coming quarters and years. And so I'm just curious
column7: as capabilities on generative AI have evolved over the past 12
column9: have your thoughts evolved in terms of the opportunities
column10: threats
column11: investment requirements on this front?

column1: And is it fair to say that as it relates to 2025 specifically
column2: generative AI is maybe more an efficiency gain than a top line driver? Or how would you kind of bifurcate the impact in 2025 specifically?"|"Martina
column3: in your prepared remarks
column4: I think I caught you saying that you'd lean more into practical AI applications in the coming quarters and years. And so I'm just curious
column5: as capabilities on generative AI have evolved over the past 12
column6: 24 months
column7: have your thoughts evolved in terms of the opportunities
column9: investment requirements on this front?

column1: And is it fair to say that as it relates to 2025 specifically
column2: generative AI is maybe more an efficiency gain than a top line driver? Or how would you kind of bifurcate the impact in 2025 specifically?"
Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column5: thanks so much for the question. Well
column6: we have -- I would say we're about
column7: as you said
column8: kind of 2 years or so into generative AI. And we absolutely continue to believe that this is really a fundamentally transformational technology. And our ability to integrate that technology and apply that technology
column9: both to our internal operations as well to our products
column10: is a core importance to us.

column1: We weren't surprised
column2: I would say
column3: in terms of how the capabilities have evolved most recently in the sense that similar to other technology innovations
column4: we would have expected the cost to decrease over a period of time.

column1: But I would note that we have been creating our products
column2: either internal or external products
column3: out of our BAU investments. Over the past several years
column4: we have a really strong innovation flywheel with Kensho
column5: which everybody in the organization has been benefiting from as well as
column6: obviously
column7: our clients.

column1: Fair to say certainly that '24 is more of an efficiency drive. That being said
column2: we're obviously not separating out the detailed specifics here
column3: and we do have a very healthy pipeline of ways in which we plan to generate value
column4: both on the efficiency front and the revenue front as we go forward.

column1: I would also say that our ability to continue to prioritize investments in this area is going to be important. We have done this out of BAU. We've been able to balance the margin expansion this year
column2: for example
column3: in the guidance and continue to invest in generative AI. We're going to want to make sure we can continue to invest going forward to generate more and more value from this technology. Thanks for the question."|Andrew
column4: thanks so much for the question.

column5: I'd like to talk about synergy realization. You seem to be executing really well there in terms of the degree of realization you see happening in '25. column6: whether that could present an uplift to overall benefits there.|Martina

column2: Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column5: thanks so much for your question. Yes
column6: we are very pleased on the synergy realization. We came into the year ahead of target on both the cross-sell and new product synergies. So overall
column7: quite excited
column8: and we expect to continue the pace of realization of synergies through the time line as we had planned. So that's an area of good momentum for us.

column1: I might separate out a little bit the -- how we think about the Vitality Index and AI products. So on the Vitality Index
column2: these are products which
column3: as you know
column4: will come in and out of the index
column5: depending on their level of maturity.

column1: We have very robust governance process for making sure that we're tracking the Vitality revenues
column2: and we are pleased to be targeting at or above 10% for 2025. That is a great indication of our ability to have strong innovative product launches and generate return on investment from those products.

column1: As it relates to AI
column2: I do think that we will see continued innovation through AI. I think this is going to come through both enhancements to our current products. So just to give you a couple of examples there. The Document Intelligence capability and the ChatIQ capability on Capital IQ Pro were launched just a few months ago
column3: and we've already had about 60
column4: 000 users benefiting from those capabilities on Capital IQ Pro
column5: for example.

column1: We've also had our new product
column2: the one that I was mentioning
column3: just to give you that as an example
column4: the Kensho LLM-ready API. We're having dozens of conversations with our clients right now because of the need and interest from our clients to integrate our data into their own LLM applications internally.

column1: So I would expect to see more of that type of activity as we go forward. We have lots of innovation in the pipeline
column2: and that will contribute to our ability to grow our business in the next several years. Thanks so much for the question
column3: Pete."|Pete
column4: thanks so much for your question.

column2: Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column5: thanks for your question. Well
column6: with Ratings being a market-driven business and
column7: of course
column8: you see this with Index as well
column9: we do come in with a broader guidance range than we do for the subscription businesses. And of course

column1: I would say the level of volatility that we are seeing is
column2: we'll say
column3: not completely foreign in the sense that this market has experienced intense volatility over a period of time now. And our ability to predict where the market is going to go is really informed by how we -- what we're hearing from our customers.

column1: That's obviously the most important part of this is actually getting the feedback directly from customers
column2: and that's obviously informing our guidance as we go forward.

column1: But of course
column2: we're also
column3: as I had mentioned
column4: looking at the maturity walls. We're looking at the issuance environment from the perspective of interest rates and spreads as well as opportunistic activity. Those are all features of the bottom-up builds that we do when we're creating the billed issuance guide
column5: for example.

column1: And I would say maybe some of the other things to think about into the long term would be GDP rates. Over a longer period of time
column2: issuance ultimately is much more closely correlated to GDP. But our guidance for this year
column3: of course
column4: has an embedded base case for GDP.

column1: I would say the level of volatility that we are seeing is

column3: not completely foreign in the sense that this market has experienced intense volatility over a period of time now. And our ability to predict where the market is going to go is really informed by how we -- what we're hearing from our customers.

column3: some great opportunities within our CARFAX business. We've seen great results from the integration of Market Scan
column4: good flows on dealers
column5: et cetera.

column5: I would say
column6: headwinds in the Mobility sector are taken into consideration as part of the guidance for 2025."|Yes.

column2: Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column5: thanks so much for the question. I think the engagements and the sentiment
column6: I would say
column7: differs by region. So within the U.S.
column9: we've seen quite a lot of optimism in the private markets. We've seen optimism for M&A deal flow. We've seen
column10: obviously
column11: consistent with some of the financials reporting really strongly
column12: some optimism there as well and interest in our products.

column1: I think that maybe varies a little bit depending on if you're in Europe or Asia
column2: where you may have some more muted feedback
column3: let's say
column4: and more kind of a neutral outlook. And so the feedback tends to vary. I think in every one of these conversations
column5: everyone is another opportunity for us to help our clients in some way.

column1: We -- the number of times that I've been able to say
column2: ""Hey
column3: we cover that from a research standpoint in this division or that group
column4: and then provide some of the research or point to where they can access information
column5: that's very valuable for our customers
column6: and we'll continue to do that.

column1: We always say that we're here in the good times as well as the challenging times. And to the extent that our customers are concerned
